I always feel a little bit sad by how short-lived some species are. Whether that be Digger Bees, like the aforementioned or octopus and many more. They work so hard, all their little lives, just to provide for their young, and when that task is over, it's like their clock has run out. They'll never see the fruits of their labor and its just kinda bittersweet. But this is the way of the world and how it has to be in order for everything in nature to stay perfectly balanced, just as it is.
Such fascinating creatures have such short lives... It's a bit sad, but whatareyagonnado? 🤷🏾‍♀️ That's nature.

Hi Deep Look, I'm a pollinator ecologist and was just wondering what you meant when you said  Anthophora bomboides cannot sting, because as far as I know, they most certainly can. It seems to be a common misconception that I've seen often in pollinator outreach that 'native bees cannot sting' and I'm not sure where this originated, as there's no truth to it, at least not in North America (there are stingless native bees in other parts of the world). Just curious if there's something I don't know about A. bomboides in particular, or if perhaps instead this statement in the video is not as clear as it could be (i.e., males cannot sting, but females can). Thank you!

The thing that astounds me is this drive for males to mate and for females to build intricate nests and lay eggs until it dies!!
Why such an extreme mode of existance?
Did the bees that did things in moderation to live another year fail continously and only those bees with an obsessive drive to mate and build only survive...
Or are these bees conscious of the shortness of their existance and as a result choose to go all out to leave a progeny?!
If the later then this might flip the understanding of insect neurology upside down and mean that even such a simple creature has awareness and that awareness is not exclusive to creatures such as humans, apes, elephants, dolphins, porpoises and whales...
Awarenesss is a general trait of many living things.

There are two kinds of bees:
-Adorable, fluffy, friend-shaped ones like these sand castle building lads.
-The hyper aggressive, evolutionarily flawed, blood craving psychopaths known as Carpenter Bees.

I HIGHLY prefer the former over the latter. I am trying to recover from what is essentially PTSD: Bee edition because one of those carpenter bees chased me all the way up the street when I was younger. The only thing holding me back from going into conservation as a career is my fear of those carpenter bees. Anyone have any suggestions on how to finally overcome this fear?
